loans.name: Joana

texts.en:
Joana is 31 years old, originally from Maputo. After finishing primary school, in 2005, she moved to Ponta D’Ouro, a beach village boardering South Africa famous for its tourism, where her father and five other siblings live. Joana is single mother, with two girls, ages 10 and 8, who are both attending school.

Shortly after her arrival in Ponta D’Ouro, Joana opened her own food stand in the road, near the central market. In early 2007, she got a job in one of the most famous hotels in the region as a cleaning lady. As a permanent employee she makes MTn 1,650 per month (around US$65). Her younger brother who lives with her and whom she supports, is working at the food stand during the day. They make from MTn 100 to MTn 1,500 per day at the stand, depending on the season. As he is also looking for work, Joana is already searching for someone that she can rely on to attend the food stand.

This is Joana’s first loan with Hluvuku and she is very excited about it. With this MTn 3,200 she plans to increase the inventory of her stand in order to prepare for South African holidays in April and May. In the future, Joana would like to ask for a new loan to expand her business in order to help her improve her house and potentially build a bathroom.

loans.use: Increase inventory

Each week, Charity makes approximately 70 Sudanese pounds in profit and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy cattle,construct houses for rent and pay the school fees for her child.

Charity is joined in her small group by Catherine T., Esterina E., Charity B., and Joice P.. Catherine T. has a business in selling charcoal and wants to increase her inventory of charcoal.

Esterina E. is currently operating a business in selling charcoal and wants a loan to open up a shop.

Charity B. operates a business of selling beer and wants to expand her business.

Joice P. is currently in the business of selling beer and is requesting a loan to buy livestock.

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.fr:
Antoinette A. is from a disadvantaged family. She has always had the goal of getting out of her initially precarious situation. She is succeeding with the support of her husband and financial help from her parents in getting settled in her food selling business, which has experienced appreciable change. A very ambitious individual, she made contact with Alidé and is benefiting from a loan that she renewed twice. These days, her working capital went from 200,000 francs to 800,000 francs [$500 to $2,000 USD]; her booth, which was constructed of fragile materials in the beginning, has become an actual bar--restaurant, where customers benefit from the comfort. Ms. A. helps her husband a lot at home. With her profits, she has created two other sales outlets and has acquired a parcel of land. She was born around 1975 in Bonou in the wealthy county of Oueme. Married, she is the mother of three children, one of whom is in school. Of good character, she has come to request this fourth loan to position herself better in the competitive catering market in Benin.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Dame A. Antoinette est issue d’un milieu défavorisé. Elle a toujours eu pour objectif de sortir de sa situation initiale de précarité. Elle réussit avec l’appui de son mari et l’aide financière de ses parents à installer son activité de vente de nourriture qui connaît une évolution appréciable. Très ambitieuse, elle entre en contact avec ALIDé et bénéficie d’un crédit qu’elle renouvelle deux fois. Aujourd’hui, son fond de roulement est passé de 200 à 800 milles francs ; sa baraque construite en matériaux précaires au départ est devenue un véritable bar restaurant où la clientèle bénéficie d’un bon confort. Dame A. Antoinette aide beaucoup son mari au foyer. Avec son bénéfice, elle a créé deux autres postes de vente et acquis une parcelle. Elle est née vers 1975 à BONOU dans le riche département de l'OUEME. Mariée, elle est mère de 3 enfants dont 1 scolarisé. D'une bonne moralité, elle vient solliciter ce quatrième crédit pour mieux se positionner sur le marché concurrentiel de la restauration au Bénin.

loans.use: To buy 10 sheep, 5 sacks of corn, 100 kg of cassava flour, and various condiments

He needs this loan to renovate his shop before this summer. He also will add some new shelves, because fruit gets cheaper in the summer and sell very fast.

loans.use: To renovate his food shop

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard A. is a 46-year-old entrepreneur who lives with his family in Nyalenda, one of the slums in Kisumu, Kenya. He is the very hardworking and industrious proprietor of a dressmaking business which he initiated in 1989. He specializes in making women's dresses and school uniforms. The location of his shop coupled with many years of doing good business within the community has earned him a good reputation and a wide customer base. With access to the KMET/KIVA loan he will be able to expand his business. He intends to open a new tailoring shop and buy more machines and an additional stock of dressmaking materials with the US $700 he has applied for.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Open a new tailoring shop and buy more machines and an additional stock of dressmaking materials

loans.name: Thierno Omar

texts.fr:
Thierno Omar S. has been a shopkeeper for ten years in Thiès. He sells foodstuffs and would like to build his capital in order to diversify his products. He is a married father of two children, and his ambition is to open other stores in different areas. He needs working capital in order to keep up with the fast turnover of his supplies.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Thierno Omar S. est commerçant depuis 10 années dans la ville de Thiès, il fait du commerce de denrées alimentaires, et voudrait renforcer son capital afin de diversifier ses produits. Il est marié et père de 2 enfants et affiche l’ambition d’ouvrir d’autres boutiques dans des zones différentes. Il a un besoin de fonds de roulement du fait de la rotation rapide de ses stocks.

loans.use: Obtaining working capital to increase his product supply

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for UIMCEC, a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

He is a very earnest man whose ambition is to open a large store, where he will carry everything his customers ask for. He is requesting a loan to diversify his product supply and to improve his hardware store.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Mabousso G. excerce une activite commerciale depuis 3 années, il fait de la quincaillerie dans un endroit étroit dans le vieux quartier de Mbambara à Thiès. C’est un garçon très sérieux qui ambitionne d’ouvrir un grand magasin où il disposera de tous les produits réclamés par la clientèle. il sollicite un credit pour diversifier son stock et renforcer sa boutique de quincaillerie .

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for UIMCEC, a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Emin

texts.en: B. Emin is an internally displaced person (IDP) from Jabrayil. He has been working as taxi driver for 4 years. "This is enough time for a car to start needing repairs, especially when it's used as a taxi," Emin says. He has gathered some money and did general repairs to the car. He just needs to install new seats. He will use this loan also to print taxi cards with his number to distribute to clients. Part of this loan will be spent on brochures that will contain a bit of information about Azerbaijani villages and other sightseeing places where Emin invites his clients to travel. He knows all regions and does not charge clients a lot for taking them out to regions as a guide.

loans.use: To repair his taxi, purchase business cards and print travel brochures

loans.name: Natig

texts.en: H. Natig, a taxi driver, is an internally displaced person (IDP) from Aghdam. He rents a car from his neighbor to use for his taxi service. His neighbor offered to let him to pay four months' rent in advance and get one month for free. He needs this loan to take advantage of this agreement, which will save him $250, enough to send his children to the village for one month of the summer holidays.

loans.use: To rent a car for his taxi service

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Moustapha

texts.fr:
Mr. D. is a craftsman who is specialized in canvas work and who does business at Moussanté, the main market in Thiès. In his workshop, he has a few machines that he uses to sew handbags. The finished products are transported for sale to the capital, Dakar, and the rest are sent to his brother in Gambia. As is the case with all businesses of this type, one must be able to acquire the raw materials necessary to be able to fill all of the orders.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Mr D. est un artisan spécialisé dans la tapisserie dans le grand marché de « Moussanté » à Thiès. Il dispose dans son atelier de quelques machines avec lesquelles il coud les sacs à mains. Le produit fini est acheminé dans la capitale Dakar où une bonne partie est écoulée et le reste est envoyé chez son frère en gambie. Comme dans toutes les activités de ce genre, il faut pouvoir assurer l’acquisition de matières premières pour pouvoir honorer les commandes.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials to fill his orders

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for UIMCEC, a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick O. is a 36-year-old husband and father of three school-aged children. He lives in one of the slums of Kisumu, Kenya, and runs the longest-standing community pharmacy in his area. He received his certificate for the pharmacy training after finishing secondary school in 1993 and has since been working from this location. Considering his 14 years of good work, the community knows him personally. Patrick has also trained as a community health worker and has been providing home-based care services for people living with HIV/AIDS for the past four years. He sells his drugs at affordable prices due to financial status of the community he serves. His highest selling products are painkillers, antimalarials, family planning drugs, allergy medications, those treating ulcers, worms, and skin infections, and various syrups for children treating malaria and upper respiratory infections. His vast knowledge and experience, positive attitude, and kindness have earned him a good reputation within his community. His well-established business has been quite successful due to his loyal and wide client base. Patrick requires an additional US $700 to further expand his community pharmacy, purchase drug stocks in bulk and also pay for rent.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Pharmacy expansion and buy stock of drugs.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth D. is a 52-year-old widow who supports four children in her household. She specializes in making women’s dresses and men’s shirts. Elizabeth is well-known for her dressmaking skills in the community, and this has attracted old and new customers. She constantly updates her materials to keep with the current fashions, offers a wide selection of patterns, and maintains a good stock to meet her customers’ demands. Her hard work, years of experience, and well-established client base ensure that her business will continue to succeed. Elizabeth plans to expand her business to include sale of new fast-moving ready-made clothes. She plans to use half of her next loan of US $700 to purchase a stock of ready-made clothes and also to invest part of it in buying new patterns and materials.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Purchase stock of ready-made clothes and also buy new patterns and materials.

loans.name: Elnura

texts.en: A. Elnura rents a small shop next to her house where she sells bed sheets, blankets and women's and children's clothing. She has 3 children. Her husband was in hospital for 2 weeks and had surgery. She had to spend money from the shop to pay for her husband's medical expenses. Now she needs a loan to purchase inventory for her shop. Her son is 21 years old and also supports them as much as he can. He is painter and works in construction of small houses.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her clothing store

loans.name: Teresia's Tuungane Group

She now hopes for a loan to buy more raw materials to increase her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who have businesses dealing in weaving sales and spare parts sales.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace W. is a 50-year-old married mother of two living children. She has spent twenty-three years running her small vegetable kiosk in the outskirts of Kisumu, Kenya. She has integrated her business to include cereals to enable her to maximize her profits. Her hard work, perseverance, good reputation and many years in business coupled with a well-established client base ensure that her business will continue to grow despite stiff competition. Grace has received three previous loans from KMET/KIVA which she has used to scale up her business in order to cope up with the demand. She has applied for a loan of US $700. She plans to purchase an additional stock of cereals and vegetables and save the balance to use in case of unforeseen circumstances.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Purchase additional stock of cereals and vegetables.

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en:
Dr. Andrew O. (standing second left with clinic staff) is a general practitioner managing his own private facility in Kisumu, Kenya. He is 44 years old and lives with his wife and six school-aged children. He was employed by the government for the first three years of his career. He then worked at a private hospital for six years before starting his own practice in 1997. He ran his current facility on a part-time basis using it primarily for admissions, while his main practice remained in the center of town. He gradually focused his efforts on building a larger out-patient facility at this location and eventually shifted his client base here three and a half years ago. Besides general curative services and an observation ward, his facility offers a pharmacy, a laboratory and maternal and child health services. Dr. O. attributes his success to hard work, perseverance and assistance from KMET’s/KIVA's previous three microfinance loans. He has been able to expand his facility, increase the number of services he offers and improve the quality of care he provides. Dr. O. also carries a very good reputation from his many years of good work in Kisumu. His practice continues to grow as he attracts more corporate clients as well as private patients. Dr O. plans to purchase additional of drugs in bulk with US $1200 he has applied for.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Purchase additional stock of drugs

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane O. is a 46-year-old community health worker (CHW). She lives in Kisumu, Kenya, with her husband and seven children (3 sons and 4 daughters). In the year 1988 she started her butchery business. In 2002 she was then trained by KMET in home-based HIV/AIDS care. Through hard work and perseverance aided by four previous KMET/ KIVA microfinance loans, Jane has managed to expand her business and build a successful community pharmacy. Her reputation and friendly approach to her clients and customers has earned her respect in the community. Jane requires an additional US $800 in order to further expand her pharmacy and butchery business.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Purchase stock of drugs for her pharmacy and also expand her butchery business.

loans.name: Zakia

texts.en:
Zakia is 33-years-old and is married with four children; ages 15, 9, 6 and 2. Zakia has been selling soft drinks since 2005. She works from 9AM to 7PM and earns approximately $250 per month.

Zakia has taken out one successful loan to expand her business. She now hopes for another loan to increase her inventory of soft drinks for resale.

loans.use: To increase inventory of soft drinks for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith A. is a 27-year-old mother of three children. Judith and her husband live in Kisumu, Kenya. Judith has received three microfinance loans from KMET. She began her tailoring business in the year 2000 in Rongo, Kenya. In 2006 she moved her business location to Kisumu to join her husband who works in Kisumu. Since then she has successfully built a business due to the added advantage of access to loan capital from KMET/KIVA, hard work and perseverance. She specializes in both men's and women's dresses.

The central location of her shop and her many years of doing good business within the community have gained her a good reputation and a wide customer base. Her business has done quite well due to the added advantage of access to loan funds; she has combined the additional money with hard work and perseverance in order to increase her stock and materials and build a successful income-generating business.

Judith is proud of her accomplishments and that she is now able to contribute to paying household expenses. To further expand her business she has applied for US $700 to enable her to purchase a variety of clothes-making materials and also purchase other stock and tailoring supplies to keep up with the growing demand.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Increase a variety of cloth making materials and stock of tailoring supplies.

loans.name: Zainabu's Tujijenge Group

texts.en:
Zainabu is 32-years-old and is married with 3 children; ages 12, 8 and 2. She and her husband also take care of one other 10-year-old child. Zainabu has been selling charcoal since 2004. She works from 6AM to 10PM and earns a monthly profit of approximately $160.

She now hopes for a loan to purchase more charcoal to increase her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who have businesses dealing in tailoring, selling alcohol and food vending.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal to increase sales

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Fatuma's Furaha Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is 36-years-old and is married with three children,;ages 16,12 and 7. Fatuma has been selling fish since 2003. She works from 10AM to 5PM and earns a monthly profit of $300.

Fatuma has taken out one successful loan to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more fish to increase her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in cloth and soft drinks sales.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Hadija is 26-years-old and is married with one 3-year-old child. She and her husband also take care of another 3-year-old child. Hadija sells electrical equipment. She started this business in 2006. She works from 6AM to 4PM and earns a monthly profit of $90.

She now hopes for a loan to purchase additional equipment to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory of electrical equipment

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia is 40-years-old and is married with four children; ages 24, 20, 13 and 7. She and her husband also take care of two other children, ages 13 and 8. Rukia owns a small food vendor store which she started in 1998. She works from 6AM to 10PM and earns a monthly profit of approximately $180.

Rukia has taken out one successful loan to expand her business. She now hopes for another so she can purchase more food items for resale.

loans.use: To purchase additional food products for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Mboni

texts.en:
Mboni is 36-years-old and is married with 3 children; ages 12, 7 and 2. Mboni owns a small stationery store and is also a cloth seller. She began these businesses in 2000. She works from 8AM to 9PM and earns a monthly profit of $300 from her sales.

Mboni has taken out one successful loan. She now hopes for another to purchase more inventory items to further expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for expanding her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Doreen's Mikoroshini Group

texts.en:
Doreen is 28-years-old and is married with one 4-year-old child. She and her husband also take care of one other person. Doreen has been selling cloth since 2004. She works from 7AM to 11PM and earns a monthly profit of $350.

Doreen has taken out one successful loan to expand her business. She now hopes for another to purchase more inventory for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Zaituni, who has a cafe business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for clothing sales

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is 32-years-old and is married with 2 children, ages 8 and 4. She sells cloth and is also a wig designer. Aisha started these businesses in 2001. She works from 9AM to 7PM and can earn a monthly profit of approximately $300.

Aisha has taken out one successful loan to expand her business. She now hopes for a new loan to purchase more items for her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 38-years-old and is married with one child who is 15-years-old. Mariam sells food, a business she started in 1998. Everyday, she works from 7AM to 9PM and can earn a monthly profit of $400 from her sales.

Mariam has taken out one successful loan to expand her business. She now hopes for another to buy more inventory for her business.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Layla

texts.en: Layla is a 42-year-old woman. She works and lives with her family in Bekaa. Layla sells clothes to the neighboring inhabitants. This is the ninth time Layla has applied for a loan at A. Majmoua. She needs to buy new merchandise for her business.

loans.use: To buy new merchandise

loans.name: Nyaso

texts.en:
Nyaso is 45-years-old and is a married woman with 3 children; ages 14,7, and 4. She and her husband also take care of one other person. Nyaso makes coffins, a business she started in 2000. She works from 7AM to 8PM ands earn a monthly profit of approximately $450.

Nyaso has taken out one successful loan to expand her business. She now hopes for another loan to purchase additional raw materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is 54 years old and lives with his family in the Bekaa Valley. He has six children and makes a living selling food to his neighbors. This is the first time he has applied for a loan from A. Majmoua. He will use the proceeds to buy more of the provisions he needs to run his business.

loans.use: to buy provisions

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en: Fadi is 43 years old and lives with his family in the Bekaa Valley. He has three children and makes a living painting cars. He also repairs cars for people who live in his area. This is the fourth time Fadi has applied for a loan from  Al Majmoua. He will use the loan to buy more supplies for his business.

loans.use: to buy supplies for a car-painting business

loans.name: Amal

texts.en: Amal is 37 years old and lives with her family in the Bekaa Valley. She has five children, and makes a living selling clothing to her neighbors. This is the second time she has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua. She will use the money to buy new merchandise to sell to her customers.

loans.use: to buy new merchandise to sell to her customers

loans.name: Maher

texts.en: Maher is 27 years old and lives with his family in the Bekaa Valley. Maher is in the construction business, and is applying for his second loan from Al Majmoua. He will use the proceeds to buy the supplies he needs to run his business.

loans.use: to buy supplies for a small construction business

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima was born in 1958 and she is from a small village near the town of Travnik. She lives with her husband, who has  a full-time job, and his monthly salary is 500 KM. Fatima sells milk and cheese and she earns about 200 KM monthly.They have 3 children. This is her first loan and Fatima intends to use it to buy another cow in order to expand her cattle business.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en: Fadi is a 36 years old and lives with his family in the Bekaa Valley. He has three children and makes a living as a mechanic. This is the fifth time that Fadi has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua. He will use the money from this newest loan to buy the materials and supplies he needs to manage and expand his business.

loans.use: to buy material for a small business

loans.name: Nisrine

texts.en: Nisrine is 31 years old and works and lives with her family in the Bekaa Valley. Nisrine makes a living selling clothes, accessories, gifts and other items.  This is the fourth time she has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua. She will use the new loan to buy merchandise for her business.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to sell to her customers

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is 22 years old and works and lives with his family in the Bekaa Valley. He has three children and makes a living painting furniture. This is the second time Hussein has applied for a loan for Al Majmoua. He will use this new loan to buy supplies and materials for his business.

loans.use: to buy material for a furniture-painting business

loans.name: Mirzada

texts.en: Mirzada is a 29 year old married woman, who lives together with her husband in a small village near the town of Travnik. Her husband has a full -time job and his monthly salary is 470 KM. They have 3 cows and they sell milk to the dairy. Mirzada will use this loan to buy animal feed in order to improve the quality of her milk. Her wish is to open a mini cattle farm.

loans.use: To buy animal feed

loans.name: Badr

texts.en: Badr is 42 years old and works and lives with her family in the Bekaa Valley. She makes a living selling clothes. This is the first time Badr has applied for a loan from A. Majmoua. She will use the funds to buy additionA. merchandise to sell to her customers.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise to sell to her customers

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima is a 54 year old married woman from Rakovica, a suburb of Sarajevo. Her husband works as a carrier and his monthly income is 1000 KM. This is her first  loan and Fatima will use it to buy animal feed. Her dream is to expand the amount of cattle she owns.

loans.use: To buy animal feed.

loans.name: Adnan

texts.en: Adnan is 36 years old and lives with his family in Lebanon's Bekaa Vally. He has three children and makes a living running  cultivation projects in farming areas.  This is the first time that Adnan has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua. He plans to use the money to buy materials he needs to run and grow his business.

loans.use: to buy materials for a small business

loans.name: Maida

texts.en: Maida is a 39 year old woman from Kobiljača, a suburb of Sarajevo. Her husband works as a carrier and he can earn  about 500 KM monthly. They have 2 children, 4 and 11 years old, and the older child goes to  primary school. Maida intends to use this loan to buy more groceries for her shop. Her wish is to expand her business to offer more selection to her customers.

loans.use: Buy more groceries for the shop.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna has established a profitable business selling shoes at the busy Central Market in Khoost, Ukraine. She sells a variety of trendy shoes including styles that are especially popular with young people. Anna knows how to operate a successful business and is able to make a good, stable income each month. As the economy expands in Ukraine, and individual incomes increase, more people are able to afford higher quality and higher priced goods. Increased demand means the potential for higher earnings for entrepreneurs like Anna.

Anna has requested a loan to increase her working business capital. This loan will give her the funds to purchase additional inventory and help her continue improving her business and income.

loans.use: Increase business working capital

loans.name: Nadezhda

texts.en: Please delete this loan.

loans.use: Purchase new inventory

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is a young mother from Khoost, a city in western Ukraine. She is married and has one daughter. Nataliya helps support her family with a small clothing sales business which she operates at an outdoor market in Khoost. Nataliya has had her business for about seven years. She is kind-hearted lady and loves to visit with her customers.

Nataliya has requested a loan to increase her working capital. This is Nataliya’s second loan from Nadiya Ukraine. We are happy to have this opportunity to help her run a stable, successful business.

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Nina

texts.en:
Nina is married with children who are grown. She is from the city of Uzhgorod, where she has a small business selling meats at one of the local markets. She has been in this trade for 6 years and has many loyal customers. Nina gets a lot of help from her husband, son and daughter who all work at different vending locations in the same market.

Nina would love to earn more and continue growing her venture so she can help her children buy their own apartments. Moreover, she would also like to see her dream come true of repairing her own apartment and redesigning its interior to the way she has pictured in her mind. That is why Nina is requesting this loan. She’d like to purchase specialized equipment for her meat kiosk to help her increase her profits and reach her goals. We believe Nina’s ability to make quick and effective decisions will help her business to remain successful and prosperous in the future.

loans.use: Purchase specialized equipment

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana lives in Uzhgorod, Ukraine with her 5 year old son. She is raising him by herself and also finds the time to run her small store selling men’s, women’s, and children’s clothing. Svetlana opened this little store just recently with the help of her sister. They invested most of the money they had in equipment, rent and paperwork that needed to be done. Svetlana didn’t have much money left over to purchase inventory to sell in her store. That is why she is requesting a loan to help buy assorted merchandise.

Svetlana is very enthusiastic and self-motivated and has a high level of energy. She manages her time really well, working long hours but always setting some time aside for her son. Svetlana would like to increase her income so she can remodel the business facility she is renting and as well as her own apartment. One of her big dreams is to become the owner of a small store facility instead of just renting one. We believe Svetlana’s assertiveness and optimism will help her translate all of these ideas into reality.

loans.use: Purchase new inventory

loans.name: Lubov

texts.en:
Lubov lives in Nikopol with two children. She sells clothing and footwear in one of the local markets, which she started doing 5 years ago. Due to her highly motivated entrepreneurial spirit and a meticulous survey of the market, Lubov found her niche and customer base. Her unique ability to present her inventory and meet customers' needs are strong aspects contributing to her rapid business growth.

Lubov currently makes about $250 in profit each month. Her turnover capital is about $3000. However, Lubov believes her venture has only started to grow and still has a big potential for further expansion. She would love to open more vending facilities in Nikopol. Her strategy is to increase her stock and generate additional profits which would then be reinvested in her trade. That is why Lubov is asking for a loan to purchase new inventory and help develop and upgrade her small business.

loans.use: Purchase new inventory

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is 36 years old and lives with his family in the southern Lebanese town of Tyre. He has five children and makes a living selling yogurt and milk. This is the first time he has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua, and he intends to use the money to buy additional livestock.

loans.use: to buy livestock to produce more yogurt and milk

loans.name: Vera

texts.en:
Vera and her husband Vasiliy live in Nikopol, in eastern Ukraine. Vera is a small entrepreneur who rents a facility and has a little photo business where she offers picture printing services and sells various photo accessories. A favorable business location, reasonable prices and a nice arrangement of assorted merchandise are some of the factors that have added to the success of her venture. Vera has been in this trade for 8 years. Currently, her monthly income is about $800. She has about $5000 in inventory.

Vera is well-known as an entrepreneur of integrity and consistency. Her business has grown a lot thanks to high-quality, digital equipment she recently bought and low competition in the area where she works. Vera would like to get a loan to increase the assortment of inventory she has for sale in her store. She hopes to invest some of her generated profits into repairs on her house and to purchase some household appliances.

loans.use: Purchase inventory

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is 26 years old and lives in southern Lebanon, in the town of Tyre. He is single and makes his living as a butcher. This is the first time he has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua. Ali plans to use the money to buy livestock to sell from his shop.

loans.use: to buy livestock to sell to his customers

loans.name: Riad

texts.en: Riad is 44 years old and lives with his family in the town of Tyre in southern Lebanon. He has three children and makes a living as a barber. This is the fourth time he has applied for a loan at Al Majmoua. He will use this newest loan to pay the rent on his shop.

loans.use: to pay the rent on his barber shop

loans.name: Jamal

texts.en: Jamal is 48 years old and lives with his family in the town of Tyre in southern Lebanon. He has five children, and makes a living selling yogurt and milk. He has applied for his third loan from Al Majmoua, and will use the money to buy additional livestock.

loans.use: to buy livestock

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Gonogorik 2016-1 Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Regina S.. She is currently in the business of selling at a shop and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Regina is 45 years old and is married with a husband who is a security guard. She has 4 children ranging from age 7 to 14 and her children go to school. Each week, Regina makes approximately 350 sudanese pound in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay fees for her children.

Regina is joined in her small group by Tabisa Amari, Ciclia P., Mary J., and Sara B.. Tabsa Amari has a business in selling bread and beer and wants to expand the business. Ciclia P. is currently operating a business in brewing alcohol and wants a loan to buy a bus for transporting goods. Mary J. operates a business of selling breads and wants to expand her business. Sara B. is currently in the business of selling vegetable and is requesting a loan to open up shop.

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Limpio Poty- Group

texts.es:
This group is called “LIMPIO POTY” which in their native language means Prospering Limpio. Limpio is the name of the city where most of these women from the same neighborhood come from. This group was formed through a contact made with a member from another group in the area with her neighbor who was interested in the program.

Before the loan, they had four meetings in which the members became familiar with the Group for Entrepreneurial Women program and agreed the conditions they have to meet to join. They are now in the program's 5th cycle; their credit is about $65 to $260 for each of them.

The money they are asking for will be invested in their respective micro-businesses, including: clothing and shoe sales, lingerie sales, produce sales, hardware sales, plastic utensil sales, jewelry sales, and notions, etc.

Translated by Joanne Egnatchik, Kiva volunteer

El nombre de este comité es “LIMPIO POTY” palabras que en garran que significan “Limpio floreciente”; Limpio es el nombre de la ciudad de donde provienen estas señoras vecinas todas del mismo barrio. Este comité se formo a partir de un contacto realizado por una integrante de otro comité de la misma zona con una vecina suya interesada en el programa.

Se realizaron cuatro reuniones previas al crédito en donde las interesadas se interiorizaron más a cerca del programa Comité de mujeres emprendedoras y aceptaron las condiciones que debían seguir para formar su grupo. Actualmente se encuentran en el 5º ciclo del programa, la línea de crédito que manejan es de entre G. 300.000 y G. 1.200.000 cada una (un aproximado de $65 y $260 cada una).

El dinero que solicitan es para invertirlo en sus respectivas micro empresas, entre las cuales podemos citar: venta de ropas y zapatos, venta de lencerías para damas, venta de frutas y verduras, ferretería, venta de utensilios de plástico, bijouterie (joyas), productos de mercería, entre otros.

loans.use:
Purchase merchandise like: clothing, sheets, towels, shoes, produce, sweets, meat, cheese, jewelry, perfumes, lingerie, thread, etc.

Compra de mercaderías como: ropas, sabanas, toallas, zapatos, verduras y frutas, golosinas, carne, queso, bijouterie, perfumes, lencería, hilos, etc.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María Estela is 48 years old, single, and the mother of two children, both of whom are college students. She is a high-quality dressmaker and has been self-employed for 18 years and in the business for 30 years. She started as seamstress assistant, and she used her small salary to study couture and design. Now she is a respected designer and dressmaker among their clients. She says that, thanks to her experience and the friendships she has made, she has made high-level economic contacts and has independently entered the market.

In addition to having her own client base, she also works with businesses, schools and universities making uniforms. With time she has made progress, and today she has three employers that work in her shop. Her dream is to have a boutique in downtown Asunción so that she can be closer to her clients and help other women like herself find work.

María Estela has asked for a loan to purchase general supplies wholesale, such as fabrics, thread, fasteners, elastic, buttons, pins, etc. since the demand for school and business uniforms has increased and she wants to fill all of her orders.

Translated by Joanne Egnatchik, Kiva volunteer

La Sra. María Estela tiene 48 años de edad, es soltera, tiene dos hijos, ambos estudiantes universitarios. La Sra. Estela es modista de alta costura, tiene una antigüedad de 18 años como trabajadora independiente y se dedica a esta profesión hace 30 años. Se inició como ayudante de costura, con su pequeño salario estudiar alta costura y posteriormente estudió diseño de modas. Hoy día ya es una diseñadora y costurera muy prestigiada entre sus clientes, comenta que gracias a la experiencia y las amistades que sembró tuvo muchos contactos de muy buen nivel económico y así se abrió al mercado en forma independiente.

Además de tener clientes independientes, también trabaja con empresas, colegios y universidades en la elaboración de uniformes. Con el tiempo ella a progresado bastante y hoy día ya posee un grupo de tres empleados que trabajan en su taller y su sueño es habilitar una boutique en el centro de la ciudad de Asunción para así poder estar más cerca de sus clientes y ayudar a otras mujeres que como ella empiezan desde abajo dándoles fuente de trabajo.

María Estela nos ha solicitado un crédito para la compra de insumos en general y en cantidades industriales tales como: telas, hilos, cierres, goma, botones, broches y otros pues la demanda de uniformes para colegios y empresas ha aumentado y desea cubrir todos sus pedidos.

loans.use:
Purchase of general supplies, such as: fabric, thread, fasteners, elastic, buttons, pins, etc.

Compra de insumos en general tales como: telas, hilos,cierres,goma, botones,broches y otros.

loans.name: Mujeres Solidarias Group

texts.es:
The committee known as "Mujeres SolidA." from the Villa Madrid de Limpio area was formed thanks to previously formed groups that grew large and were then divided to reduce the number of ladies in each group. Thus this new group of entrepreneurs was formed.

These ladies are enterprising women, who above and beyond managing their own microbusinesses are also mothers and housewives. They persist daily to maintain their families. Their principal motivation is their children, since they all desire that their children study and have better luck than their mothers have had.

Currently these women are in the third cycle of the program. They manage a line of credit of from 300, 000 guaranies (Paraguayan currency) to 800,000 guaranies per member. Currently there are 16 members; each works in a different activity, such as lingerie sales, sales of fast food, jewelry sales, fruit and vegetable sales, beverage sales, sweets, products by catalog, etc.

They possess a great enterprising spirit and want to continue growing. They are happy with the program since the training they receive helps them a lot. The loans are also a great help since the women invest them in their microbusinesses. Currently they are requesting a new loan which they want to invest in the purchase of merchandise to sell.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

El comité denominado “Mujeres SolidA.” de la compañía Villa Madrid de Limpio se formo gracias a otros grupos que se formaron anteriormente y para reducir el número de señoras se dividieron y formaron otro grupo más.

Estas señoras son mujeres emprendedoras, que además de manejar sus propias microempresas también son madres y amas de casa. Ellas luchan día a día por mantener a sus familias, sus principales motores son sus hijos, ya que el deseo de ellas es que todos estudien y tengan una mejor suerte que las de ellas.

Actualmente se encuentran en el 3º ciclo del programa, la línea de crédito que manejan estas señoras es de G. 300.000 hasta G. 800.000 por cada integrante, actualmente son 16 integrantes y cada una trabaja en actividades diferentes como venta de lencería, venta de comidas rápidas, venta de joyas, venta de frutas y verduras, venta de bebidas, golosinas, productos por catálogo, etc.

Ellas poseen un gran espíritu emprendedor y desean seguir creciendo, están contentas con el programa pues las ayuda mucho con las capacitaciones que reciben. Los créditos también son de mucha ayuda ya que los invierten en sus microempresas. Hoy día están solicitando un nuevo crédito que lo desean invertir en la compra de mercaderías para la venta.

loans.use: Buy merchandise such as lingerie, meat, fruits and vegetables, silver jewelry, sweets, perfumes and cosmetics.

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es:
Oscar Domínguez está casado y tiene dos hijas pequeñas que están aun en edad escolar. Oscar cuenta con una despensa bien surtida hace siete años, anteriormente era chofer repartidor de una empresa de productos de consumo masivo después de unos años pudo ahorrar y decidió independizarse montando un negocio en su propia casa.

El negocio ya tiene nueve años de antigüedad y posee una muy buena clientela formada, especialmente por vecinos de la zona. Oscar dice que gracias a los créditos que recibió de la Fundación Paraguaya pudo progresar y mantener su negocio y familia, también adquirió una moto que hoy lo utiliza para realizar repartos a domicilio.

El sueño de Oscar es poder ofrecer a sus hijas la posibilidad de estudiar en la universidad para ser profesionales, ya que él no contó con esa oportunidad; y para ello ya ha empezado a ahorrar.

Oscar solicita un crédito con el que desea surtir de mayor variedad su despensa, de este modo sus clientes no tendrán necesidad a recurrir a supermercados para la compra de artículos de primera necesidad.

loans.use: Compra de harina, yerba, leche, panificados, bebidas en general, productos enlatados, productos de limpieza, entre otros artículos de primera necesidad.

loans.name: Perla

texts.es:
Perla G. is marrried and mother of two small children, both still too young to go to school. Perla used to work as a employee in a supermarket in the city, where she was reponsible for events and promotions.

After a few years of sacrifice working at the supermarket with neither paid vacation days nor paid holidays, she put together some savings and decided to work independently. She began teaching crafts in local schools. Later she bought a sewing machine with a loan and began to do dressmaking in her house while still teaching at the schools.

Thanks to the fact that she maintained both jobs she was able to continue saving. Later her children were born, a change which motivated her to work more and more at home. Her husband works in the meat department of a supermarket and with his salary provides the family's income. A year ago Perla with her motivation to move ahead also opened a kiosk in her home thanks to some savings and a new loan from Fundación Paraguaya.

These days Perla would like to receive another loan, which she will invest in the purchase of merchandise for her kiosk and cloth and thread for her sewing business.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Perla G., esta casada y es madre de dos hijos aun muy pequeños que todavía no van a la escuela. Perla trabajaba como empleada en un supermercado de la ciudad, ella era encargada de eventos y promociones.

Luego de varios años de trabajo sacrificado en el supermercado pues no tenía días libres ni feriados, ella junto unos ahorros y decidió trabajar de forma independiente. Empezó enseñando manualidades en escuelas de la zona, luego un crédito anterior compro una máquina de coser con los que empezó a realizar trabajos de costura en su casa a la par que enseñaba en las escuelas.

Gracias a que mantenía ambos trabajos pudo seguir ahorrando, luego vinieron los hijos cosa que también influyo para que cada vez trabaje más en su casa. Su marido trabaja en un supermercado en la sección de carnicería y con su sueldo aporta a los ingresos de la familia. Hace un año Perla en su afán de salir adelante también montó un kiosco en su casa gracias a unos ahorros y un nuevo crédito que recibió de la Fundación Paraguaya.

Hoy día desea adquirir un nuevo crédito, el que lo invertirá para la compra de mercaderías para su kiosco y telas e hilos para realizar sus costuras.

loans.use: Purchase of different types of thread and cloth, soft drinks, juices, sweets, baked goods, etc.

loans.name: Vielsa

texts.es:
Mrs. Vielsa is 31 years old and married for 12 years. Her husband works in a factory and provides for the home with his salary. They have three children, all minors and attending the primary school.

Mrs. Vielsa owns a small stand from where she sells food to the workers in the area. She has this business for the last 7 years. Her main customers are the workers and employees of the different companies in the area. Her business is well located in the center of the city of Mariano R. Alonso, which has a lot of people traffic.

She started the business with the capital that she received as severance when the company for which she worked went bankrupt and closed. She comments that one of her goals is to rent a large commercial space and open a diner that will offer better meals for her customers. She would also expand her sale of other consumer products all in one location.

She is requesting the loan for the purchase of merchandise such as meat, flour, cooking oil, eggs, milk, tea (yerba mate), baked goods and beverages in general.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Vielsa tiene 31 años de edad, esta casada hace 12 años, su marido es empleado de una fábrica y aporta con su salario para los gastos del hogar, tienen 3 hijos, todos menores y estudiantes de la educación escolar básica.

La Sra. Vielsa es propietaria de un pequeño puesto kiosco donde también da de comer a trabajadores de la zona. Ella posee este negocio hace 7 años, sus principales clientes son los obreros y empleados de las diferentes empresas de la zona, su negocio tiene una buena ubicación ya que se encuentra en el centro de la ciudad de Mariano R. Alonso donde existe mucha población activa.

Se inició con un capital adquirido con el pago de su indemnización salarial cuando la empresa donde trabajaba quebró y cerró. Comenta que uno de sus objetivos es alquilar un salón comercial amplio y así montar comedor que ofrezca mejores comodidades a sus clientes y además amplíe su tienda para la venta de otros productos de primera necesidad en un solo lugar.

Solicita el crédito para la compra de mercaderías como: carne, harina, aceite, huevos, leche, yerba mate, panificados y bebidas en general.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise such as meats, flour, cooking oil, eggs, milk, tea (yerba mate), baked goods and beverages in general

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es:
Oscar D. is married and has two school age daughters.Oscar has owned a well-stocked convenience store for seven years. Previously he was a delivery driver for a consumer products business. After a few years he was able to save and decided to launch his own business out of his house.

The business is now 9 years old and boasts a well developed clientele, especially among his neighbors. Oscar says that thanks to the loans that he has received from Fundación Paraguay he was able to progress in his business and maintain both the business and his family. He also purchased a motorcycle that he uses to make home deliveries.

Oscar's dream is to be able to offer his daughters the possibility of studying in the university and becoming professional women, since he did not have that opportunity. He has already begun to save for this dream.

Oscar is requesting a loan with which he wants to stock a wider variety of products in his store, so that his clients will not have to turn to supermarkets for the purchase of convenience items.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Oscar Domínguez está casado y tiene dos hijas pequeñas que están aun en edad escolar. Oscar cuenta con una despensa bien surtida hace siete años, anteriormente era chofer repartidor de una empresa de productos de consumo masivo después de unos años pudo ahorrar y decidió independizarse montando un negocio en su propia casa.

El negocio ya tiene nueve años de antigüedad y posee una muy buena clientela formada, especialmente por vecinos de la zona. Oscar dice que gracias a los créditos que recibió de la Fundación Paraguaya pudo progresar y mantener su negocio y familia, también adquirió una moto que hoy lo utiliza para realizar repartos a domicilio.

El sueño de Oscar es poder ofrecer a sus hijas la posibilidad de estudiar en la universidad para ser profesionales, ya que él no contó con esa oportunidad; y para ello ya ha empezado a ahorrar.

Oscar solicita un crédito con el que desea surtir de mayor variedad su despensa, de este modo sus clientes no tendrán necesidad a recurrir a supermercados para la compra de artículos de primera necesidad.

loans.use: Purchase flour, herbs, milk, baked goods, beverages, canned good, cleaning products and other convenience items.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Mrs. María Magdalena O. is a married woman; she is 39 years old. Her husband's name is Rubén Gaona; he is 46 years old. They have three children, all in secondary school. They own their own home where they have a business selling items for fishing and bait.

In 1997, they started a convenience store with Rubén's savings. As the years went on they gradually added fishing and bait items to the store because the clientele were requesting these items, since they live close to the river, in a busy fishing area.

Some years later they formally specialized in fishing supplies, since this was turning out to be the most profitable part of the business. Maria's husband works for the city government. He is the private secretary of the governor and provides the family's income with his salary.

They began to work with Fundación Paraguay in 2003 and comment that thanks to the loans the Foundation has provided them, their business has gone along growing daily. They are requesting a new loan for the purchase of more merchandise since this is the season of the year with the greatest inflow of fisherman to the area.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Maria Magdalena O. es una mujer casada y tiene 39 años de edad y su esposo se llama Rubén Gaona y tiene 46 años de edad, tienen tres hijos, todos en edad secundaria, posee una casa propia y en la misma tienen un negocio de ventas de artículos para pesca y carnadas.

En el año 1997 empezaron con una despensa la cual fue formada gracias al ahorro de su esposo, pero después con los años a dicho negocio fue incorporando algunos artículos de pesca y carnadas, porque la clientela lo solicitaba ya que viven cerca del río y hay mucha gente que se dedica a la pesca en esa zona.

Luego de unos años se dedicaron ya a la venta de los insumos para pesca pues esto le resultaba mucho más rentable. El esposo de María trabaja en la gobernación de la ciudad, el es secretario privado del Gobernador y aporta al ingreso familiar con su sueldo.

Ellos empezaron a trabajar con la Fundación Paraguaya en el año 2003, y comentan que gracias a los préstamos que se le otorgo su negocio fue creciendo cada día. Es por eso que están solicitando un nuevo préstamo para la compra de más mercaderías ya que en esta época del año hay mayor afluencia de pescadores en la zona.

loans.use: To buy merchandise: reels, fishing poles, lanterns, lead weights, fishing hooks, bait and other fishing supplies.

loans.name: Neh

texts.en:
Neh was born in 1957, married and a mother of six children. Her challenges have been that of sickness, marital misunderstanding and the destruction of her property during a political uproar. Her husband’s unemployment also made it difficult for her family to feed well and for her children to go to school. This led her to seek help and to become a member of GHAPE where she was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline. Since then, she has invested and repaid all her loans with which she raised money to pay school fees for her children, buy a plot, build a house and buy food for her family.

Neh is requesting a new loan to carry out the business of patching and selling tires,engine oil and crop cultivation. Her son, who has experience in the repair of tires, will take care of the workshop. The shop is situated along the main road with access to many clients. With this, she will raise money to continue paying her children’s school fees, buy medications and to complete her house.

She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Purchase tires and buying of seeds for crop cultivation

loans.name: Maria De Jesús

texts.es:
Ms. Maria de Jesús has been creating floral arrangements for over 12 years. “This business is my family’s sole source of income, since I am a single mother who's trying to help my children get ahead in life. I need more supplies for my flower shop so that the arrangements can be ready for delivery. I am requesting a loan of $1,200.00 USD so that I can purchase the supplies I need for my flower shop and promptly ship my customers’ orders.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Maria de Jesús tiene ya más de 12 años dedicándose a los arreglos florales. "Este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de mi familia ya que soy madre soltera y con este negocio e sacado a mis hijos a delante. En la florería me esta haciendo falta mas material para tener listos los arreglos y entregar unos pedidos que tengo. Solicito un préstamo de $1,200.00 Dlls para la comprar de material para la florería y así poder entregar los pedidos que tengo a tiempo a mis clientes."

loans.use: Purchase supplies for flower shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Lydia Achini

texts.en:
Lydia was born in 1969. She is married to John Nikwi and they have nine children. Her husband abandoned her and the children. This led to the death of two children due to poverty and suffering. She says being alone and paying rent is a difficult burden on her.

She has to start doing some of those things her husband did. Challenged by these realities she has double her effort towards meeting the needs of her children like paying schools fees, providing medication and food.

This made her join GHAPE. Given a loan, she plans to rear pigs, crop cultivation and do trading. Her community stands a chance of benefiting from her activities, as she will provide them with food and manure, which will help increase agricultural output.

She plans to repay the loan in 24 months and her first installment repayment will begin on the fourth month from date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of piglets, seedlings and trading

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan L. is married with six children. She has been with GHAPE for six years and was motivated to join the program by other members after being mistreated by her husband. With her meager income, she faced the burden of taking care of her children. With a loan from GHAPE, she was able to provide the family with basic needs.

Given a new loan, she plans to invest in motorbike transport, which is of high demand in her locality and pig farming. She believes the business will be lucrative because the people in the locality are highly in need of public transport (Motor bike taxi) due to the poor condition of roads. Also, she will pay for the documents of the bike like insurance and helmets. With the training she received from GHAPE on raring pigs she wishes to expand her pig farm by buying more piglets, feed and repair the existing fence. She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Purchase of motorbike and piglets

loans.name: Nchang

texts.en:
R. is married to a polygamist and has 5 children. Educating her five children in both, the formal and informal sector is her primary goal. Borrowing from neighbors at very high interest rate has been her lifestyle before receiving her first loan from GHAPE. She invested the loan in crop cultivation. Before receiving her first loan she was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline, which is been reinforced during the monthly meeting she attends. Her community stands to benefit from experience marketing skills and supply of foodstuff from rural farms to markets.

R. plans to buy a motorbike taxi which is commonly used in her locality and is of high demand. Also, from her farm harvest she will provide the community with food.

She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Purchase of motorbike and seedlings

loans.name: Nji

texts.en:
C. was born in 1962. She's married and has six children. Her difficulties in life have been that of poor health, educating the children, feeding them and the lack of farming tools. With all this she had to join GHAPE where she received training in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline. Since then, she has repaid all her loans with which she raised money to pay school fees for the children and provide them with food and medication.

Given a new loan , she plans to buy rice, palm oil, and various food items to sell in front of her house since her house is located along a public road. Also, these food items are of high demand in her locality. Part of the loan will be invested in mixed farming and will provide food items in the local market. She plans to pay her loan in 18 months. Her first installment repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Purchase of food item and seedlings,

loans.name: Hostensia

texts.en:
Hostensia M. is a widow with four children. Her difficulties in life have been that of educating her children. The worst moment came when she lost two daughters over a short period of time. These children being the eldest had the responsibility of being the breadwinner for the family. With this grate loss she was unable to provide the basic needs for the remaining children.

With the loan she plans to buy piglets, feed, medication for pigs and also plank and nails to repair and expand her pig farm. She will use part of the money to maintain one of her houses that she will give out to rent. This will help provide shelter for others and the manure will be used to cultivate her crops and improve the output. She plans to repay her loan in 24months.Her first installment will be done on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan

loans.use: Buying of piglets, feed and seedlings and repair materials

loans.name: Cynthia Margarita

texts.es:
Cynthia Margarita Guzmán started her business 2 years ago. What motivated her to do so was that fact that she did not have enough money, and she was constantly struggling due to her financial difficulties. Her husband’s income as a security guard is not sufficient. As their son grows, so do the family expenses, and those expenses have frequently emerged these days. Because of this alarming situation, Cynthia saw the need to work for herself. This is how she began her shoe sale business, first selling her products from home because she could not leave her house; her child was too young. Now that her son is older, she has changed her sales strategy; she goes door-to-door offering her products and rotating her merchandise.

She is requesting a loan of $300.00 USD, which she is willing to repay in 6 months, so that she can purchase more merchandise that has been requested and order more products for the new season. Let’s help Cynthia so that her business may prosper.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

Cyntia Margarita Guzmán comenzó hace 2 años lo que la impulso a desarrollar esta actividad porque no tenia dinero suficiente y siempre batallaba debido las carencias económicas ya que el trabajo de guardia de su esposo no le deja mucho dinero y conforme su hijo crecía los gastos también, a ultimas fechas sucedía con mayor frecuencia, como la situación se ponía mas alarmante pues la necesidad la hizo trabajar por su cuenta. De esta manera inicio su negocio de venta de calzado vendiendo primero calzado en su casa porque no podía salir ya que su niño estaba todavía muy pequeño, ahora que ya esta mas grande cambio su estrategia de venta, sale a la calle a ofrecer los productos y de esta manera lograr rotación de la mercancía.

Ella solicita un crédito por US $300 que esta dispuesta a pagar en 6 meses lo que la va apoyar para poder surtir mas mercancía que tiene pendiente y poder encargar mas productos para la nueva temporada. Ayudemos a Cyntia para que su negocio prospere.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise (footwear)

loans.name: Clorinda

texts.es:
Mrs. Clorinda Pérez S. is a member of the “Banco Comunal, Nuestra Señora de la Paz”, she lives in the Region of San Martín, province of San Martín, district of Tarapoto. Her address is Pasaje 6 de Septiembre No. 336 in the area of Huayco where her business, a carpenter’s workshop, is located. The opportunity of a loan from the “Banco Comunal” will allow her, together with her husband, to develop this business and be prepared with capital for the time when schools request furniture. Doña Clorinda also works as a teacher at a local educational center.

With the loan of S/.800.00 ($300.00) to be repaid in six months, she will purchase 250 feet of wood in order to manufacture the furniture of the orders placed. She is 44 years old, lives with her husband and 3 children, but only the youngest depends on her. She works in coordination with her husband who is making the carpentry.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Clorinda Pérez S. pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuestra Señora de la Paz” vive en la Región San Martín, provincia de San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto, su domicilio está ubicado en el Pasaje 6 de Septiembre Nº 336 en el Barrio Huayco donde también funciona su taller de Carpintería, negocio al que se dedica. La oportunidad de un préstamo en el Banco Comunal le permite desarrollar junto a su esposo este negocio y estar preparados con un capital para las temporadas en las que los colegios solicitan mobiliario, paralelo a esta actividad ella presta servicios como profesora en un centro educativo local.

Con el crédito de S/. 800.00 el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará 250 pies de madera que le servirá para fabricar los pedidos de mobiliarios La señora Clorinda tiene 44 años, vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos dependiendo de ella sólo el último, trabaja en coordinación con su esposo ya que el es el que realiza los trabajos de carpintería.

loans.use: Purchase wood to manufacture furniture.

loans.name: Guldith

texts.es:
La señora Clorinda Pérez Salas pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuestra Señora de la Paz” vive en la Región San Martín, provincia de San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto, su domicilio está ubicado en el Pasaje 6 de Setiembre Nº 336 en el Barrio Huayco donde también funciona su taller de Carpintería, negocio al que se dedica. 

La oportunidad de un préstamo en el Banco Comunal  le permite desarrollar junto a su esposo este negocio y estar preparados con un capital para las temporadas en las que los colegios solicitan mobiliario, paralelo a esta actividad ella presta servicios como profesora en un centro educativo local. 

Con el crédito de S/. 800.00 el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará 250 pies de madera que le servirá para fabricar los pedidos de mobiliarios

La señora Clorinda tiene 44 años, vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos dependiendo de ella sólo el último, trabaja en coordinación con su esposo ya que el es el que realiza los trabajos de carpintería.

loans.use: Con el prestamo comprara prodcutos para su negocio

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his business

loans.name: Luz Maria

texts.es:
a señora Luz Marina C. L. D. Escudero pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manos Unidas” vive en la Región San Mrs. Luz Marina C. L. D. Escudero is a member of the “Banco Comunal, Manos Unidas”, she lives in the Region of San Martín, Province of San Martín, District of Morales, and her address is Fonavi Mz “F” Lote 2, where her business of groceries – general store is located. The opportunity of a loan from the “Banco Comunal” will allow her to develop her business and to stay with her children, reason why she left a previous job. She is grateful to the “Banco Comunal” for being able to expand her business and she feels satisfied and happy with strength to go on expanding her business and to set up a restaurant in the premises. She also works with delivery service.

With the loan of S/.3,000.00 ( $1,100.00) to be repaid in 6 months, she will purchase sacks of rice, sugar, personal care and home care products, soft drinks, different variety of candy, and thus meet the needs of her customers. Doña Luz Marina is 48 years old, lives with her husband and 3 children. Her children assist her in serving the customers and in the delivery service.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Luz Marina C. L. D. Escudero pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manos Unidas” vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia D. San Martín, distrito D. Morales, su domicilio está ubicado en Fonavi Mz “F” Lote 2, donD. también se ubica su negocio D. venta D. abarrotes – bodega. La oportunidad D. un préstamo en el Banco Comunal le permite desarrollar este negocio y poder estar junto a sus hijos, motivo por el cual dejó un trabajo. Agradece al B.C porque pudo ampliar su negocio y se siente realizada y feliz, con mucha fuerza para seguir ampliando el negocio e instalar a la par un restaurante en su mismo local. Asimismo trabaja con servicios D. delivery.

Con el crédito D. S/. 3,000.00 el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará sacos D. arroz, azúcar, productos D. aseo personal y D. limpieza para el hogar, bebidas gaseosas, golosinas en diversas variedades, y así satisfacer la necesidad D. sus clientes. La señora Luz Marina tiene 48 años, vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos, en el trabajo le ayudan sus hijos en lo que respecta a la atención al cliente y los servicios D. delivery.

loans.use: Purchase more products to make business grow and be able to set up a restaurant.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Manuela Ramos / CrediMUJER - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more store merchandise and more sawdust for making bricks

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in raw materials and cleaning products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To enlarge her business and repair the storefront

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest on more merchandise for her bar and continue building

loans.name: La Franbruesa Group

texts.en:
Ana M. is a lovely young woman who lives with her four children and husband in the town of Los Alcarrizzos, a suburb of the capital of Santo Domingo. She has started a small business providing public transportation to her community members. Ana is requesting this loan so that she can improve the service she provides to her clients, making her car safer, more comfortable, and more fuel efficient. With the profits from her business, she hopes to begin saving more money, working towards realizing her dream of one day returning to school so that she can become college-educated; as well, she hopes to be able to help send her children to college. She says that it is often difficult to advance economically in Los Alcarrizzos, but with hard work and this loan, she believes she can improve her life and business, one day at a time.

On behalf of everyone here at Esperanza International, and from Ana M. herself, we thank you for your support with this micro loan!

loans.use: To purchase car parts and pay maintenance costs.

loans.name: Las Asusenas Group

texts.en:
Antonio is a 47 year-old man who never stops working hard, nor trying to improve the quality of his life. He lives in an impoverished community on the outskirts of the capital of Santo Domingo with his wife and an additional six family members.

He has owned a small colmado for some time, but is requesting this loan to improve, expand and grow his little business. A colmado, a very common type of business in the Dominican Republic, is essentially a small grocery store that offers community members basic food provisions (rice, beans, vegetables), as well as soaps, beverages, and miscellaneous household items. With the loan, he plans to expand his range of inventory and thereby attract new clients.

He dreams of one day having his own large grocery store, not just a neighborhood colmado, and believes that by continuing to work hard, saving, and being responsible, it is a real possibility. He insists that his children continue studying so that they can be productive members of society, and hopes that he himself will always progress in both his personal and economic life.

On behalf of everyone here at Esperanza International, and from Antonio himself, we thank you for your support with this micro loan!

loans.use: To purchase household goods and food products

loans.name: Luis Alberto

texts.es:
Mr. Luis Alberto C. L. is an agricultural and livestock producer who has worked 100% since his very early youth on his agricultural and livestock production. He is a family man and feels responsible to maintain his two children who need help on their education because they are minors.

His wife is a very hardworking woman who also supports him on his production activities in order to improve their lives and be able to go on with their family life. Aware of the needs his family is going through, Mr. Luis Alberto has been demanding loans from CEPRODEL for the last 9 years. He has used those loans to buy seeds for harvest and to buy kettle for raising. He comes to Ceprodel today again to ask for a loan that may allow him to go on with his business and give his very beloved family the support they deserve.

Translated from Spanish by Veronica MR, Kiva volunteer

El señor Luis Alberto C. L., es un productor agropecuario que ha trabajado desde su juventud cien por ciento en sus actividades agrícolas, pecuarios y crianza de animales. Es un padre de familia con la responsabilidad de mantener a sus dos hijos los cuales demandan apoyo en su educaron porque son menores de edad.

Su esposa es una dama muy esforzada que también lo apoya en su actividad económica para lograr sacar adelante su hogar y así mejorar las condiciones de vida de la familia. Consiente de la necesidad que atraviesa su familia, el señor Luis Alberto desde hace 9 años ha realizado créditos en CEPRODEL los cuales le han permitido la compra de granos para la cosecha y además la compra de ganado para su respectiva crianza. Hoy en día una vez mas acude a Ceprodel para obtener el crédito que le permita continuar con su negocio y de esta manera brindarle el oportuno apoyo a su familia que tanto ama mucho.

loans.use: To buy seeds for harvest and kettle

loans.name: Guldith

texts.es:
Mrs. Guldith N. Rodríguez is a member of the “Banco Comunal, Nuestra Sra. de la Paz”, she lives in the Region of San Martín, Province of San Martín, District of Tarapoto, and her address is Av. Micaela Bastidas No. 335 where her business of groceries- general store also is located. The opportunity of a loan from the “Banco Comunal” will allow her to expand this business and create income in order to help her parents. Doña Guldith is also teaching at a local educational center and when she is absent her mother is taking responsibility for the business.

With the loan of S/.2,000.00 ($725.00) to be repaid in 6 months, she will buy sacks of rice, sugar, “Kolynos”, toilet paper, boxes of soap and other products to supply her general store. She will also buy raw material to prepare snacks to be sold at her business. Doña Guldith is 39 years old, lives with her parents who she supports in all aspects, and they assist her in the development of the activities of the business.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Guldith N. Rodríguez pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuestra Sra. De la Paz” vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia de San Martín, Distrito de Tarapoto, su domicilio está ubicado en la Av. Micaela Bastidas Nº 335, donde también se ubica su negocio de venta de abarrotes – bodega. La oportunidad de un préstamo en el Banco Comunal le permite desarrollar este negocio y generar un ingreso para poder ayudar a sus padres, paralelo a este negocio es docente en un centro educativo local, y cuando está ausente su mamá se responsabiliza del negocio.

Con el crédito de S/. 2,000.00 el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará sacos de arroz, azúcar, Kolynos, papel higiénico, jabones en cajas y otros productos para surtir su bodega , asimismo productos para producir un poco de bocaditos que los expende en su negocio. La señora Guldith tiene 39 años, vive con sus padres a quienes apoya en todo aspecto y quienes le ayudan en el desarrollo de las actividades del negocio.

loans.use: Purchase products to expand business and improve sales.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Manuela Ramos / CrediMUJER - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Maria Edith

texts.es:
Mrs. María Edith Navarro P. is a member of the “Banco Comunal, Manos Unidas”, she lives in the Region of San Martín, Province of San Martín, District of Tarapoto, her address is Jr. Sinchi Roca No. 430, where she also runs a business of renting rooms. She also teaches at an educational center of the town. The opportunity of a loan from Manuela Ramos will allow her to improve the infrastructure of the rooms for rent so she can offer better service. Her entire family supports this business.
